case_vignette:
A 50-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine checkup. He has had a progressively increasing swelling on the nape of his neck for 2 months. He does not have a fever or any discharge from the swelling. He underwent a colectomy for colon cancer at the age of 43 years. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoarthritis of the left knee. Current medications include insulin glargine, metformin, enalapril, and naproxen. He has worked as a traffic warden for the past 6 years and frequently plays golf. He appears healthy. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 130/86 mm Hg. Examination of the neck shows a 2.5-cm (1-in) firm, mobile, and painless nodule. The skin over the nodule cannot be pinched. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? [1]
The original text contains the following gender-specific references:
* "A 50-year-old man"
* "He" (multiple instances)
* "His" (multiple instances)
* "He has worked as a traffic warden for the past 6 years and frequently plays golf" (assuming the traffic warden is male)
* "He appears healthy" (assuming the person is male)

They have type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoarthritis of the left knee. Current medications include insulin glargine, metformin, enalapril, and naproxen. They have worked as a traffic warden for the past 6 years and frequently engage in golf. They appear healthy.
